metadata.titleEn: Modeling results of soil evaporation in the middle and lower Heihe River Basin at the north of Qilian Mountains (2001-2015)
metadata.description: The dataset of soil evaporation in the middle and lower Heihe River Basin at the north of Qilian Mountains (2001-2015) is stimulated by the Hydrological-Ecological Integrated watershed Flow Model (HEIFLOW). HEIFLOW is a three-dimensional distributed eco-hydrological coupling model, integrating the Precipitation-Runoff Modeling System (PRMS) with the Modular Groundwater Flow Model (MODFLOW) and several ecological modules, which can completely describe the hydrological cycle and vegetation ecological process of the basin. For the modeling details of generating this data, please refer to Han et al. (2021), and for the technical details of HEIFLOW  model, please refer to Han et al. (2021), Tian et al. (2018), and sun et al. (2018)

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method employed to simulate soil evaporation in the middle and lower reaches of a river basin, specifically using an integrated eco-hydrological model?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method for simulating soil evaporation in the middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin involves using the HEIFLOW model. This three-dimensional distributed eco-hydrological model combines a surface water model (PRMS), a groundwater model (MODFLOW), and several ecological modules to comprehensively describe watershed water cycles and vegetation ecological processes. The model generated monthly simulation data from 2001 to 2015.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key features of the ecological and hydrological processes modeled in the HEIFLOW system for simulating soil evaporation in the Qilian Mountains' Heihe River basin?
Feature Specification.Answer: three-dimensional, distributed, integrates surface water model (PRMS), integrates groundwater model (MODFLOW), includes ecological modules, comprehensive description of watershed water cycles, vegetation ecological processes

Quantification.Question: How many years of soil evaporation data were simulated using the ecological hydrological coupling model HEIFLOW?

Definition.Question: What is the HEIFLOW model in the context of simulating soil evaporation data?
Definition.Answer: The HEIFLOW model is a three-dimensional distributed ecohydrological simulation that includes a surface water model (PRMS), a groundwater model (MODFLOW), and several ecological modules. It is used to comprehensively describe watershed water cycles and vegetation ecological processes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the primary causes that influence the accuracy and reliability of soil evaporation simulation data in the Heihe River Basin using an ecohydrological model?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The accuracy and reliability of soil evaporation simulation data in the Heihe River Basin are influenced by the integration of surface water, groundwater, and ecological modules in the HEIFLOW model. The model's ability to accurately describe watershed water cycles and vegetation ecological processes, as detailed by Han et al. (2021), Tian et al. (2018), and Sun et al. (2018), plays a crucial role.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the ultimate goal of simulating soil evaporation data in the Heihe River Basin using a coupled eco-hydrological model like HEIFLOW?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to achieve a comprehensive understanding of the water cycle and vegetation ecological processes in the Heihe River Basin by utilizing the HEIFLOW model, which integrates surface water, groundwater, and ecological modules to simulate soil evaporation on a monthly basis from 2001 to 2015.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in using the HEIFLOW model to simulate soil evaporation data in the Heihe River Basin?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The HEIFLOW model, a three-dimensional distributed eco-hydrological simulation, is used to generate soil evaporation data. It integrates a surface water model (PRMS), a groundwater model (MODFLOW), and several ecological modules to describe the water cycle and vegetation ecological processes in the basin. For further modeling details, references include Han et al. (2021), Tian et al. (2018), and Sun et al. (2018).
